Award.AbstractNarration: Cognition in the human brain depends upon extraordinarily precise connections between brain cells (neurons). If neural pathways do not form correctly or become damaged, then impairments of brain function will inevitably result. Although a great deal is known about molecules that comprise connections between brain cells (synapses) there is only a rudimentary understanding of the molecular markers that direct any particular neuron to its correct target destination. The goal of this project is employ electrophysiological, molecular, and immunocytochemical approaches to identify molecules that specify selective synaptic connectivity between brain cells. The brain area to be studied is the hippocampus, a structure known to be important for learning and memory in all mammals, including humans. The hippocampus is highly organized, with clear patterns of connectivity between distinct cell populations. The initial focus will be to build upon preliminary data which indicate that potential "signpost" molecules show cell-type specific distribution patterns. Subsequent experiments will manipulate these molecules to test directly their role in directing synapse formation between specific populations of cells. Student participation will be encouraged throughout all aspects of this work and results will be disseminated at public meetings and via scientific publications. The significance and impact of these studies is clear. In order to fully understand how brains form in embryos and young organisms throughout the animal kingdom, fundamental knowledge must be obtained about how individual cells are able to seek out and form synapses with their correct targets. The work described here will make an important contribution to achieving that goal.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The human brain is an organ of enormous computational power.  It contains over 80 billion nerve cells (neurons) that make over 100 trillion connections (synapses) with one another.  At present, the cellular mechanisms that orchestrate formation of the human neural network are poorly understood, which is unfortunate because more knowledge about these fundamental processes would aid the treatment of neurodevelopmental diseases such as autism spectrum disorders.  To provide a foundation for such work, we studied the formation of synaptic connections of murine neurons in tissue culture, a system perfect for evaluating molecules that could promote (synaptogenic) or prevent (anti-synaptogenic) synapse formation.  To avoid uncertainties, we focused on effects of a synthetic molecule known as EphA3-Fc.  EphA3 is a member of the ephrin-A/EphA family of ligands and receptors which have been shown to be membrane-bound and capable of regulating synaptic connectivity.  EphA3-Fc, however, is a commercially available, engineered molecule in which the intracellular kinase domain has been removed and replaced with an Fc fragment.  EphA3-Fc can be used in activated (clustered) or non-activated (unclustered) forms, and when added to cultures can influence “reverse” signaling (e.g. activation of a membrane-bound ligand by clustered EphA3-Fc) as well as interfere with “forward” signaling (e.g. suppression of endogenous ligand-to-receptor interaction by unclustered EphA3-Fc).  The data show clearly that clustered EphA3-Fc is potentially synaptogenic, and support the idea that ephrin-A/EphA signaling plays a role in brain development.  These experiments have been included in a doctoral thesis and have been presented at professional meetings as well as more informal student gatherings.
